III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A (16) is residing in Wedgewood Christian Center. On
06/09/2025, it was disclosed that Youth A consumed laundry
detergent. Youth A was not being supervised, and she was
supposed to be supervised when she did laundry. Youth A has
drunk detergent in the past. Youth A reported she was throwing up
and she tried to tell staff, but they reported she was lying. Youth A
was sent to nursing and reported her stomach was hurting. Youth
A was provided with medication and sent back to class. Alleged
Perpetrator: Unknown.
Investigation Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
with the MDHHS Worker on 7/10/2025. He reported Youth A can
do Youth A’s laundry and it is a life skill that is taught to the youth
in the program. Youth A is allowed to do laundry but under
supervision since the laundry room is locked. He reported Youth A
has been on a 1:1 supervision level from 3/24/25 to 6/22/25. This
1:1 supervision level began because of Youth A becoming
dysregulated and engaging in swallowing items such as screws
and paperclips. As Youth A became more emotionally regulated
and stable, the 1:1 supervision was lifted. Administrator1 reported
the 1:1 is not for a 24-hour time frame per day but when Youth A
is dysregulated, which generally occurs in the afternoon after
school and the daily structure is not as structured as during the
school time. Administrator 1 reported if Youth A displays
2

dysregulation, the facility can place Youth A back on 1:1 when
necessary. Regarding the laundry for Youth A, Administrator 1
reported the laundry soap is kept in the chemical closet, which is
locked, and staff are responsible for providing the laundry soap for
youth. In the case of Youth A and because of her history most of
the time, Youth A is not allowed to have liquid items because
Youth A will claim to swallow the liquid. Therefore, staff will place
the laundry soap into the washing machine for Youth A.
Administrator 1 reported when Youth A is doing well, in an effort to
help develop Youth A’s independent living skills, Youth A is
allowed to put laundry soap in the washing machine but with direct
supervision. Administrator 1 was interviewed again via phone
with MDHHS Worker on 7/11/2025. He reported the information
of Youth A swallowing a screw will be passed on to staff and
Youth A will be placed on a safety plan again with suicide
precautions. He reported this action will be documented and this
documentation involves 15-minute (variable and interval)
observations logged. He reported Youth A swallowing a screw will
be documented and reported with follow up with Therapist within
30-minutes to complete an evaluation. He reported the 1:1
supervision will be back in place for Youth A with a focus on
helping Youth A become successful. Administrator 1 was
interviewed for the third time face-to-face at the facility with
the MDHHS Worker on 7/29/2025. This interview was a result of
the latest allegations made by Youth A. Administrator 1 reported
being aware of Youth A breaking lights on the milieu over the
weekend and Youth A broke a soap dispenser while attempting to
drink soap. He reported Youth A is on “precautions” which
involves Youth A not going to school because there is less
supervision available in the classroom. He reported the bathrooms
are locked and Youth A’s activities and movements are limited
because of the self-harming threat Youth A presents. He reported
Youth A’s history is wanting to be moved from this placement and
returned home although, going home is not an option. Youth A
has made allegations against Youth A’s father in the past and
Youth A’s parents are not able to provide the level of care Youth A
requires. Administrator 1 reported Youth A feels isolated from
having no contact with Youth A’s family and will seek negative
attention by threatening to harm others on the unit (staff and
youth). He reported the unit is still using the safety plan that was
developed at the beginning of the investigation with Youth A. He
reported there is no toilet bowl cleaner on the unit and Youth A
changed the story when telling Nurse 1 later in the day.
Administrator 1 was interviewed for the fourth time face-to-
face at the facility with the MDHHS Worker on 8/6/2025. He
was able to provide the video of the day in the latest allegations by
3

Youth A, for review (reviewed below). He reported the process for
youth cleaning is that staff will spray a cleaner on the surface of
the item to be cleaned and the youth will wipe the surface. Youth
are not to have possession of any cleaning chemical, especially
Youth A with Youth A’s history of allegedly drinking substances.
He reported again, all cleaning supplies are kept in a locked closet
and youth are not allowed in the closet. He reported not knowing
the specific cleaning item placed in the water in the blue bucket
but is sure no toilet cleaner (has bleach) is used in the program.
He reported this information (issues with youth) is discussed in
team email and team meetings and the program has been
modified because of Youth A’s behaviors. The program is losing
the ability to provide independent living skills because it requires
youth to have responsibility for things that Youth A is unable to do,
so restrictions (youth can’t pour laundry soap in machine, no liquid
soap in bathrooms) have become the norm.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with
the MDHHS Worker on 7/10/2025. She reported each youth has
a scheduled day for laundry. She reported the laundry soap is
kept in the chemical closet with the rest of the cleaning chemicals
and no youth are allowed inside this closet. She reported the
laundry soap is kept in a large tub and dispensed into a small
measuring cup when needed. The measuring cup is then carried
to the locked laundry room and poured into the washing machine
by staff or youth (Staff supervise if youth pour). She reported
youth are not allowed to pour the soap into the washing machine if
there are restrictions on the youth. She described the restrictions
(safety plan) on Youth A as Youth A is not to handle any liquid
items because of a history of allegations of swallowing the liquid.
This includes liquid hygiene items and cleaning items for the
kitchen. Supervisor 1 reported there is no more than a minimal
amount of liquid laundry soap in the measuring cup at a time. She
reported Youth A is not on a 1:1 in the laundry room but staff are
to be present when the youth (if allowed as part of independent
living training) pours in the liquid soap. Supervisor 1 was asked
about yelling at Youth A and she denied yelling but only asking
Youth A to get up.
Youth A was interviewed via phone with the MDHHS Worker
on 7/11/2025. Youth A reported Fridays are Youth A’s laundry
day, but Youth A soils the bed sheets 2-3 days a week and will do
bedding laundry 2-3 days a week. Youth A described the laundry
process as youth are allowed in the laundry room but not in the
chemical room where the laundry soap is kept. Staff also pour the
laundry soap into the washing machine after unlocking the laundry
4

room door. Youth A reported sometimes the laundry room door is
unlocked because it doesn’t get shut all the time. Youth A was
unable to provide a specific day or time of the door being
unlocked. Regarding the chemical room, Youth A reported the
laundry soap is kept in a large container and staff bring the soap
to the laundry room in a plastic cup. Youth A reported putting the
soap in the washing machine a “couple of times” (then stated
twice a week) but most of the time, staff pour it in for Youth A.
Youth A reported staff stay in the laundry room but at times staff
will leave to handle another youth leaving the youth in the laundry
room but when Youth A did laundry today, staff stood there and
watched Youth A. Youth A was asked about the drinking of
laundry soap in the allegation and Youth A reported it happened
Thursday, June 10, 2025. Youth A described the incident as telling
Supervisor 2 that Youth A needed to do laundry because Youth
A’s sheets were soiled. Youth A reported Supervisor 2 gave Youth
A the plastic cup (described about 8-10 inches high full to the top
with liquid laundry soap) and after entering the laundry room, the
door shut behind Youth A. Youth A reported feeling suicidal this
day, so Youth A ingested more than half of the liquid laundry soap
and gave the cup back to unknown staff while telling this unknown
staff (later identified as Supervisor 1) that Youth A had drank the
liquid. Youth A reported the plastic cup is always full to the top
when staff give Youth A the cup and during this incident the
unknown staff just replied with “can’t do anything about it now”.
Youth A then remembered it was Supervisor 1 who was the staff
at the time. Youth A reported feeling nauseous and throwing up a
couple of times during the day. Youth A reported throwing up in
the bathroom at school and having a staff (unknown which staff)
tell Staff 1 about the situation. Youth A reported Staff 1 told Youth
A that Youth A needed to go to see the nurse. Youth A reported
the nurse (unable to recall who the nurse was) gave Youth A a red
pill that helped settle Youth A’s stomach. Youth A reported not
telling anyone else about this incident. Youth A was asked about a
safety plan and Youth A reported Youth A’s safety plan involves
staff having to stand and watch Youth A do things. Staff have to
supervise Youth A because of Youth A’s history of doing things
and staff should be watching Youth A all the time. Youth A
reported drinking “liquid laundry soap once every 2-3 weeks
depending on how Youth A feels”. Youth A reported the last time
Youth A drank laundry soap was on Wednesday, July 9, 2025,
after speaking with Youth A’s family and becoming “mad”. Youth A
reported this occurred at approximately 6:00 pm after telling
Supervisor 3 that Youth A needed to do laundry. Youth A
described the incident as Supervisor 3 going to the chemical
closet and getting the laundry soap and handing Youth A the
5

plastic cup which was smaller maybe 6-8 inches high. Youth A
reported Supervisor 3 left, and Youth A went into the laundry room
alone. Youth A reported drinking all of the laundry soap but didn’t
tell Supervisor 3 or any other staff after handing the empty cup to
Supervisor 3. Youth A reported Youth A’s stomach was hurting
bad, but Youth A didn’t throw up. Youth A was asked about feeling
safe and Youth A reported not feeling safe because Youth A is
able to hurt Youth A more often and “this place makes {Youth A}
want to hurt {Youth A} more”. Youth A reported swallowing a
screw Youth A found in Youth A’s bedroom today but didn’t tell
anyone of this action by Youth A. Youth A reported Supervisor 1
will yell at Youth A causing Youth A to “feel like harming myself
now”. Youth A reported this incident took place when Supervisor 1
was trying to get Youth A up in the morning and Youth A didn’t
hear Supervisor 1 so Supervisor 1 yelled. Youth A was
interviewed again face-to-face at the facility with the MDHHS
Worker on 7/29/2025. Youth A reported not understanding why
Youth A was being interviewed but the new allegations resulted in
this interview. Youth A was asked about what has occurred since
Youth A’s last interview and Youth A never mentioned the latest
allegations of Youth A allegedly drinking toilet bowl cleaner or
other chemicals. Youth A did report throwing up last Thursday
(7/24/25) because Youth A had the stomach flu that lasted until
the end of this past weekend. Youth A reported last Thursday
(7/24/25) Youth A was throwing up in the school bathroom before
telling Staff 2 that Youth A’s stomach hurt bad and Youth A had
thrown up in the bathroom. Staff 2 then contacted nursing and
took Youth A back to the unit for a “sick bed” (youth stay in their
rooms until feeling better). Youth A reported throwing up in the
hallway bathroom three times around 9:00 pm and telling staff
(unable to identify who) who looked at the vomit. Youth A reported
being off “sick bed” on Saturday. Youth A then reported additional
allegations of becoming mad at staff and breaking a soap
dispenser in the hallway bathroom and drinking the liquid soap.
Youth A reported being mad at Supervisor 2 because Youth A
believed Supervisor 2 twisted Youth A’s words and was being
rude to Youth A. Youth A reported Supervisor 2 didn’t want to talk
about Youth A’s problems when Youth A was explaining to
Supervisor 2. Youth A reported Supervisor 2 told Youth A that if
Youth A keeps breaking things on the unit (Youth A reported
breaking three lights) the other youth may jump Youth A. Youth A
reported Supervisor 2 came into the bathroom and watched Youth
A drink the soap. Home Supervisor called nursing because Youth
A had blood in the vomit. Youth A reported throwing up on
Monday (7/28/25) and Home Supervisor didn’t say anything but
called nursing, who never came to see Youth A. Youth A denied
6

drinking any other liquids since the soap and didn’t know why
Youth A threw up. Youth A reported the last thing Youth A
ingested was a week before the soap when Youth A found nails in
the soap dispenser. Youth A described the process of cleaning
the bathroom which is a chore Youth A has selected. Youth A
reported all cleaning supplies are kept in the janitor closet
(chemical closet) which is locked but according to Youth A the
door doesn’t close all the way. Youth A gets a blue bucket that
has a toilet scrubber in it and staff add toilet bowl cleaner. Youth A
will dip the scrubber in the liquid and scrub the toilet. Youth A
reported staff are in the milieu and don’t watch Youth A clean the
bathroom. Youth A reported staff will spray the sink, toilet, and
walls so Youth A can wipe them clean with a cloth. Youth A
reported Supervisor 2 doesn’t watch Youth A clean the bathroom.
Youth A reported throwing up in school the morning of this
interview and not telling any of the staff. Youth A reported a belief
that Youth A’s stomach hurts bad right now because it is burning
and may be a result of the soap Youth A drank a few days ago.
Youth A was asked about reasons for not telling and reported
being scared staff would yell at Youth A. Youth A reported not
feeling safe at the facility because the other youth want to fight
Youth A and staff would allow it to happen. Youth A was asked
about the third allegations and reported a belief that the substance
Youth A drank smelled like toilet bowl cleaner. Youth A denied
ever telling anyone Youth A drank urine cleaner (reported to
Nurse 1). Youth A was asked about the situation and reported
Supervisor 2 was supervising Youth A when Supervisor 2 left the
bathroom to help other youth and Youth A drank toilet bowl
cleaner. Youth A reported staff (unidentified by Youth A) will let
Youth A have liquid cleaner to use in the bathroom but usually
watch Youth A clean the bathroom. Youth A reported over the
weekend, she was breaking the overhead lights in the milieu,
taking a piece of broken plastic and threatening to harm other
youth and staff in the milieu but staff intervened, and no one was
hurt.
Youth B was interviewed via phone with the MDHHS Worker
on 7/11/2025. Youth B reported having Monday as Youth B’s
laundry day but being allowed to have additional time to do
laundry if needed. Youth B reported the laundry process as staff
provide the laundry soap from the chemical closet and staff, or
youth can put the soap in the washing machine depending on the
statues of the youth. Youth B reported youth are allowed in the
laundry room under the supervision of staff and the amount of
soap given to the youth to put into the machine is about 1 inch in
the plastic cup. Youth B denied the plastic cup is ever filled to the
7

top. When asked about any restrictions on youth in the laundry
room, Youth B reported Youth A is on precautions because Youth
A will drink liquid soap, therefore staff have to handle the soap or
other liquid items for Youth A. Youth B reported if staff allow Youth
A to put laundry soap into the washing machine, staff will watch
Youth A pour it in the washing machine and Youth B has never
observed Youth A in the laundry room without staff being present.
Youth A reported staff are always watching Youth A, even when
Youth A goes outside, staff are by Youth A. Youth B reported
feeling safe at the facility.
Therapist was interviewed via phone with the MDHHS Worker
on 7/11/2025. She reported just meeting with Youth A and using
Dialectical Behavioral Treatment (DBT) techniques to help Youth
A develop the mindfulness skills to handle unhealthy emotions in a
positive manner. She reported being told by Youth A that Youth A
swallowed a screw, but Youth A didn’t report where Youth A found
the screw. Therapist reported going to Nurse 1 with Youth A and
informing Nurse 1 about Youth A swallowing a screw. Youth A had
told Therapist the “screw was bigger than a normal screw”.
Therapist reported Youth A saying Youth A swallowed a screw is
a normal occurrence for Youth A as is swallowing a liquid
substance. Therapist reported never observing Youth A swallow
any of the claimed items and all reported medical examination (x-
rays) have not provided any evidence of Youth A swallowing a
metal object (screw). Therapist reported Youth A has a history of
being dishonest in an effort to seek medical treatment or extra
support from others. Therapist reported Youth A has never
reported a staff yelled at Youth A.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via phone with the MDHHS
Worker on 7/21/2025. She reported the process for laundry
services for youth in the program involves the following steps.
Youth will bring out their laundry and staff will unlock the laundry
room door, allowing the youth to place their clothing in the
washing machine. The youth will ask for laundry soap which the
staff will obtain from the locked chemical room, where the laundry
soap is kept in a large bucket. Staff will ask the youth to step out
of the laundry room while getting the laundry soap. If another staff
is available, the other staff will watch the youth in the laundry room
while the primary staff obtains the laundry soap. Supervisor 2
reported never leaving a youth alone in the laundry room and she
never allows youth to pour laundry soap into the washing
machine. She reported never observing another staff allowing
youth to be alone in the laundry room or pour laundry soap into
the washing machine. She reported working Thursday (2nd shift)
8

and Saturday and Sunday each week. Her shifts rotate between
1st shift and 2nd shift every other weekend. Supervisor 2 was
asked about Youth A and the laundry process and reported never
allowing Youth A to be alone in the laundry room or handle the
laundry soap because of Youth A’s history of drinking liquids. She
reported not allowing Youth A to touch the laundry soap on
Thursday 7/10/25 nor leaving Youth A alone in the laundry room.
She reported following the safety plan for Youth A and believes
administration is reenforcing the need to follow the policy during
the newest communication. Supervisor 2 was asked about 1:1
supervision and reported this means that staff are to not leave the
youth alone and keep eyes and ears on the youth at all times.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed again face-to-face at the facility
with the MDHHS Worker on 8/6/2025. Supervisor 2 reported
having no knowledge of the allegations and after being told of the
allegations, she denied the allegations ever took place. She
reported Youth A has never shown Supervisor 2 any vomit from
Youth A. She reported hearing from other staff (did not identify
specific staff) that Youth A has thrown up in the past. She denied
Youth A has ever told Supervisor 2 that Youth A has ingested
chemicals. She reported a belief of having a good relationship with
Youth A and trying to help Youth A heal. She reported if being
told that Youth A had ingested something harmful, she would
make sure Youth A is alright and “contact nursing” to find out what
they would want Supervisor 2 to do with the situation. She
reported she would follow nursing instructions. She reported
Youth A is not to touch any chemicals and staff spray the cleaning
solution on the surface to be cleaned and the youth will wipe the
surface clean. She reported Youth A is never to touch a chemical
and the spray bottle is never to be given to Youth A nor sat down
when Youth A is around. In regard to the blue bucket, Supervisor
2 reported not worrying about Youth A trying to grab the blue
bucket because Youth A tries complete the bathroom chore in
“about 2 seconds”. Supervisor 2 reported being notified of safety
plans through staff email and staff meetings. She reported all staff
are aware of the situation with Youth A and provide and adjust
supervision (increase if Youth A is displaying emotional
dysregulation) to the situation that Youth A presents.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed via phone with the MDHHS
Worker on 7/21/2025. She gave the same report as other staff
interviewed about the laundry process with a couple of exceptions.
She reported the laundry room and chemical rooms are locked
and the laundry soap comes from a large bucket in the chemical
room, but she has allowed some youth to pour the laundry soap
into the washing machine. She reported taking this action to help
9

the youth develop independent living skills but will watch the youth
pour the liquid into the washing machine after giving them just
enough soap for 1 load of laundry. She described this amount of
soap as very small. She denied ever observing a staff fill the
plastic cup up with laundry soap. She denied every allowing Youth
A to pour the soap into the washing machine or walking away from
Youth A leaving Youth A in the laundry room. Supervisor 3 was
asked about 7/9/25 and reported working 2nd shift that day and
didn’t recall handing laundry soap to Youth A. She reported Youth
A has a history of swallowing liquid; therefore, the safety plan is
that Youth A should not have access to any type of liquid that was
not designed for drinking. Supervisor 3 was asked about 1:1
supervision and reported this is when a staff is assigned to a
youth and this staff is to make sure the youth’s needs are being
taken care of. She reported staff are more attentive to the
assigned youth but not watching the youth when the youth is
going to the bathroom, sleeping (still completing room checks), or
showering.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone with the MDHHS Worker on
7/21/2025. She reported working as the school staff and described
the laundry process since she also works in the unit a couple of
days a week. She reported a similar laundry process with the
laundry room and chemical room being locked. Staff obtain
laundry soap from a large bucket and only pour a very small
amount into a plastic cup before pouring the liquid into the
washing machine. She reported not allowing youth to pour the
soap into the washing machine but can put their own clothes into
the washing machine. She reported youth are not allowed in the
chemical room and when in the laundry room, staff must be
watching them. Staff 1 was asked about the report Youth A gave
of throwing up several times a few months ago while in school.
Staff 1 reported not remembering an incident like that and stated
the process is to walk youth to the bathroom and back to the
classroom. She reported if a youth throws up, staff are to check
the toilet to confirm the youth threw up. She again stated this
never occurred with Youth A and Youth A would be more likely to
say Youth A’s head or stomach was hurting. Staff 1 was asked
about the 1:1 supervision and reported Youth A was on 1:1 status
last week but currently is not on 1:1 status. She reported Youth A
is doing better and stopped saying Youth A was going to find a
screw to swallow. She reported Therapist is the individual who
determines the 1:1 status for youth. She described staff’s
responsibilities for 1:1 supervision as completing a safety log
within 15-minute staggered times and hourly if staff can observe
10

the youth. Staff are to keep youth within eye sight and hearing
during 1:1 supervision.
Nurse 2 was interviewed via phone 7/25/2025. She reported
being approached by Staff 2 on Wednesday (July 23, 2025). She
reported Staff 2 informed Nurse 2 that Youth A had returned from
lunch complaining of a stomachache and Youth A had to vomit.
Staff 2 told Nurse 2 that Staff 2 did not witness the vomit but heard
Youth A vomiting in the bathroom and Youth A was not looking
well. Nurse 2 reported speaking with Youth A who stated Youth A
had a really bad stomachache because Youth A’s lunch was not
sitting well. Nurse 2 reported asking Youth A if Youth A would like
to go to the unit to rest and Youth A acknowledged that Youth A
would like to lay down and rest. Nurse 2 reported checking in on
Youth A later in the evening and an unknown staff sitting outside
of Youth A’s room (Nurse 2 could not recall who the staff was) on
the unit informed her Youth A was in the bathroom throwing up.
Nurse 2 went to the bathroom and when Youth A came out Nurse
2 took the opportunity to look at the vomit on the floor and found
that it looked like peanut butter crackers and water. Nurse 2 was
told by this unknown staff Youth A’s snack was peanut butter and
crackers with water. Nurse 2 reported Youth A asked to speak
with Nurse 2 without staff being present, saying Youth A could not
talk in front of staff. Staff 4 was the staff present, and Staff 4 left
the area so Nurse 2 could talk with Youth A. Once alone, Youth A
disclosed she drank cleaning chemicals earlier in the day. Nurse 2
reported Youth A disclosed the cleaning chemicals were
disinfectant and toilet bowl cleaner and Supervisor 2 witnessed
the event and did nothing to stop Youth A. Nurse 2 reported Youth
A stated Supervisor 2 said she could do nothing about this after
Youth A drank the chemicals. Youth A informed Nurse 2, Youth A
was feeling suicidal and was attempting to kill Youth A. Nurse 2
reported doing an assessment on Youth A and finding nothing
except a soar esophagus which would be the result of throwing up
and bringing stomach acid into the esophagus. Nurse 2 informed
Youth A not to eat or drink anything for a couple of hours then try
a sip of water. Nurse 2 reported speaking with Home Supervisor
about the situation. Nurse 2 reported Youth A has a history of
making false claims such as drinking bleach when there is no
bleach on the unit for any person to use or drink. Nurse 2 reported
all cleaning chemicals are not allowed to be handled by youth and
if a cleaning chemical is used for a chore staff will spray the
substance while watching the youth. Nurse 2 believes Supervisor
2 has a lot of integrity and would never allow a youth to handle
chemicals. Nurse 2 believes this is Youth A’s attempt to see
attention in a very unhealthy way.
11

Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with the
MDHHS Worker on 7/29/2025. She reported not being present
when Nurse 2 came to the unit to speak with Youth A after Staff 2
informed Nurse 2 that Youth A had vomited. She also reported
being present during the situation when Youth A broke the soap
dispenser in the hallway bathroom. She reported Youth A was
mad at Supervisor 2 because Supervisor 2 informed Youth A that
Youth A would have to wait to take a shower until chores were
completed. Youth A didn’t like this decision because Youth A
wanted to take a shower first. Staff 3 reported this incident took
place on Sunday (7/27/25). Staff 3 reported Staff 4 was
supervising Youth A and had just sprayed down the walls for
Youth A to wipe when Staff 4 went to the entrance of the door to
grab the mop and broom and the door slammed shut behind Staff
4. Before Staff 4 could unlock and open the door, Youth A had
broken the soap dispenser and when Staff 4 got into the
bathroom, Staff 4 observed Youth A holding soap in Youth A’s
hands but not drinking the soap. Youth A’s hands were close to
Youth A’s mouth. Staff 3 described the process of cleaning a
bathroom as staff supervise and hold the blue bucket so the youth
can dip the scrubber in the liquid (combination of Lysol and
another nontoxic substance, not toilet bowl cleaner because toilet
bowl cleaner has bleach in it and it’s not allowed on campus). The
staff will spray cleaners on the walls so youth can wipe the walls
and sink clean. Youth are not allowed to hold cleaning items. Staff
3 gave a demonstration of the cleaning and showed the cleaning
items in the chemical closet. Staff 3 ended by stating the facility is
having staff quit because of Youth A’s behaviors and blaming staff
with unfounded allegations.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with the
MDHHS Worker on 8/6/2025. He reported being present on the
unit on 7/23/25 and working with Youth A. He reported the daily
schedule involves youth having breakfast, doing chores, then
hygiene before leaving for school. He reported all cleaning
supplies are kept in the chemical closet and youth are not allowed
to possess the cleaning items. Staff are to spray the surface of the
item to be cleaned, and youth can wipe the surface. He reported

Analysis The facility is found in compliance as evidenced by interviews with
staff, youth, documents and video recording. Evidence does not
support the allegations regarding Supervisor 1 giving Youth A the
cup of laundry soap to put into the machine, it should be noted
Supervisor 1 was on suspension (not working) the day Youth A
alleged this took place. This was verified by MDHHS Worker and
Licensing because Supervisor 1 was in an interview with MDHHS
and Licensing. All other staff Youth A identified as allowing Youth
A to drink liquid soap denied it ever occurred. Youth A may
present with an inability to deal with reality and may be seeking
attention or going into a trauma cycle. Regarding the second
allegation of staff not responding appropriately to the allegation of
Youth A drinking soap there is no evidence to support this
allegation. Video reviews and interviews do not support the
allegations.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered regarding staff’s interactions
with the youth in the program as staff should not be alone with
Youth A. Technical assistance was offered regarding staff
following the procedure for laundry soap for all youth. The
confusion about who can pour the liquid and who cannot is
another thing for staff to always be aware of therefore, it might be
best practice to never allow any youth to touch the liquid soap or
not allow any youth with certain levels of mental health and
emotional wellbeing allowed in a program that wants to develop
independent living skills to the youth.
Technical assistance was offered regarding enhancing their intake
process to ensure all aspects of information needed to make an
informed decision are had and requirements of their program
statement are fulfilled.
